Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Assessing Variability in High Elevation Soil Moisture: Integrating Unmanned Aerial Vehicles, Satellites, and Field Hydrology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
An unstudied aspect of regional hydrology is the role of soil moisture in seasonal water storage, and how it is related to associated climatic, hydrogeologic and environmental dynamics. Soil moisture storage may act as a control on both water provision and primary production of key grazing lands, especially during the dry season. Variability in soil moisture therefore has an implicit role in water, food and livelihood security for downstream stakeholders. This dissertation project will investigate the patterns, processes and drivers of multi-scale temporal and spatial variability in soil moisture content (SMC) through a novel integration of multispectral Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), satellite remote sensing and field hydrology. This research will provide a scientific contribution of both methodological and technological advances in the ways that UAVs can be used in earth science and relatively inaccessible (e.g., high mountain) research as well as empirical knowledge regarding the regional hydrology of the systems under study. The findings of this research will help answer fundamental questions about the water balance of high mountain systems and responses to periodic or other climatic and anthropogenic forces. The methodological and technical advances in UAV applications will be of interest to scientists interested in new ways of mapping and understanding the earth surface. Empirical insights of this research will be of interest to scientists investigating future hydrologic scenarios as well as questions of process and scale in mountain regions. Through its focus on water availability this research has significant implications for and long-term hydrologic, energy, and economic management and planning.

This work takes place in the Cordillera Blanca range of the tropical Peruvian Andes, an area of documented scientific importance in understanding dynamic soil moisture processes and conditions. It is hypothesized that soil moisture constitutes an important yet heterogeneous reservoir of groundwater that couples glacier melt, atmospheric fluxes and land cover. To investigate these processes, this project combines the analysis of Landsat satellite imagery and high resolution (centimeter) multispectral UAV imagery with climate and hydrology data to quantify inter-annual and seasonal variability in soil moisture content (SMC). To identify potential drivers of multi-scale spatial and temporal SMC variability, this research examines the hydrogeoecological connections among SMC, groundwater storage, precipitation, glacier recession, evapotranspiration and climate in the high alpine meadows and wetlands. The systematic knowledge will contribute to many high elevation mountain systems as well as the social and economic systems dependent upon them. Lastly, this work will develop a methodology through which SMC in remote environments can be rapidly quantified with continuous coverage at a high spatial resolution using a UAV platform.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The glaciers of the Cordillera Blanca, Peru, are rapidly retreating as a result of climate change, altering the timing, quantity and quality of water available to downstream users. Changes in water availability have serious implications for ecosystems, human livelihoods and regional economies. This three-phase project has investigated spatiotemporal changes in the glacier hydrologic system of the Cordillera Blanca, with a specific focus on the spatiotemporal variability in soil moisture. 1) We developed multispectral unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) and kite platforms capable of operating at over 5000m in mountain regions. 2) We deployed these platforms to investigate processes of glacier change and surface/subsurface hydrology within the glacial valleys of the Cordillera Blanca. 3) We integrated UAV datasets with traditional field hydrology to improve our understanding of the spatiotemporal variability in soil moisture and its role in moderating groundwater storage.

This research provides a double faceted scientific contribution comprised of both methodological and technological advances in the ways in which UAV's can be used in earth science and high mountain research, as well as empirical knowledge regarding the regional hydrology of the Cordillera Blanca and more generally the tropical Andes.

We developed and extensively field tested two different UAVs, which were specially designed for deployment in high mountain regions over 4500masl. The primary UAV was a 1m diameter hexacopter fitted with visible, near infrared and thermal infrared cameras capable of fully autonomous survey missions and up to ~18mins of flight time at 5000masl. Over 20 site surveys were completed, totalling over 120 individual flights, with a maximum deployment elevation of almost 5300m, and individual flights at up to 1000m above ground level. We continue using this UAV platform in a new project in the Huancayo region of Peru to map glacier change, and we have begun testing this platform in the Cordillera Blanca to collect vertical profiles of atmospheric variables. Lessons learned from these deployments are being utilised in the development and deployment of UAVs for mapping snowpack and improving understanding of land surface hydrology in the Colorado Rockies. Additionally, a kite borne multispectral system was designed and successfully deployed in 2014 and 2015, in high wind locations. This system has been successfully deployed for other projects in the Cordillera Blanca (Somers et al 2016), and a modified version utilising a helium balloon lift system has been deployed in both Sequoia and Great Basin National Parks for other research projects. These campaigns confirm the viability of this system and approach as a simple, easy to use, high resolution mapping system in mountain zones.

We have used the UAV and derived high-resolution datasets (imagery and digital elevation models) to investigate processes of glacier change. We documented the importance of debris cover and surface features such as ice cliffs in controlling melt rates. Maps of spatial variability in soil moisture storage have improved our understanding of spatial patterns in surface and subsurface hydrology including identification of groundwater springs through their temperature signature. These maps have also confirmed the high quantities of water that can be held within the pampa and bofedale soils by providing a snapshot of spatial variability within two proglacial valleys (Llanganuco and Pachacoto). We validated UAV mapping with embedded instrumentation. We demonstrated that despite the substantial hydrologic storage potential of the bofedale soils they appear to play a limited role in buffering dry season stream flow. Rates of evapotranspiration greatly exceed the rate of storage change, indicating sizeable hydrologic inputs must be occurring to make up this deficit. Likely sources of this water are deeper confined aquifers, particularly buried talus deposits. These may buffer the groundwater table and soil moisture content through lateral flow, vertical transport and groundwater springs at the surface. Proglacial valley wetlands may still play an important role in reducing surface water runoff due to their low bulk density and high water storage capacity. They could also increase recharge rates of the groundwater system during the wet season, which may indirectly contribute to dry season stream flow.

Our results show that UAVs are effective for studying heterogeneous landscapes at high resolution, and are thus highly suited for small scale glacier-hydrology change studies in mountain regions. We have had broader impacts to the growing field of UAV applications by advancing the engineering limitations of this technology, opening up a range of future scientific opportunities in other areas. In the context of water availability, this research has important implications for rural livelihoods and long-term hydrologic, energy, economic and development planning in Peru.
